No—Gatsby turned out all right at the end; it is what preyed on Gatsby, what foul dust floated in the wake of his dreams that temporarily closed out my interest in the abortive sorrows and short-winded elations of men.

I felt a shiver run down my spine as I gazed at them, my mind racing with questions. Who were these women, and how did they end up on this couch, suspended in mid-air? I took a step forward, my eyes fixed on the women, and that was when I noticed something strange - a faint humming noise, like the gentle buzzing of a harp string, seemed to be emanating from the couch itself. I hesitated for a moment, wondering if I should investigate further, but my curiosity got the better of me, and I took another step forward, my eyes fixed on the women, who remained motionless, their faces still serene, their bodies still buoyed up by some unseen force.

es_first_half: El único objeto que permanecía absolutamente inmóvil en la habitación era un enorme sofá en el que dos jóvenes flotaban como sobre un globo sujeto a tierra. Las dos iban de blanco y sus vestidos ondeaban y aleteaban como recién llegados de un vuelo fugaz alrededor de la casa. Tuve que permanecer de pie un
es_second_half: rato, escuchando los latigazos de las cortinas y el chirriar de un cuadro en la pared. Entonces se oyó una explosión: Tom Buchanan había cerrado las ventanas traseras, y cesó el viento atrapado en la habitación, y las cortinas, los tapices y los vestidos de las dos mujeres volvieron a posarse lentamente en el suelo.
es_results: momento para observar a las dos jóvenes, que parecían estar en un estado de éxtasis, sus ojos cerrados y sus rostros iluminados por una sonrisa beatífica. El sofá, que parecía ser el único objeto que no había sido afectado por la extraña energía que había invadido la habitación, se encontraba en un estado de quietud
es_results_raw: momento para observar a las dos jóvenes, que parecían estar en un estado de éxtasis, sus ojos cerrados y sus rostros iluminados por una sonrisa beatífica. El sofá, que parecía ser el único objeto que no había sido afectado por la extraña energía que había invadido la habitación, se encontraba en un estado de quietud absoluta, como si estuviera esperando a que las dos jóvenes se despertaran de su trance. La habitación en sí misma parecía estar en un estado de suspensión, como si el tiempo hubiera dejado de fluir en ese momento. El silencio era absoluto, solo roto por el suave movimiento de los vestidos de las jóvenes, que se mecían suavemente en el aire. De repente, una de las jóvenes abrió los ojos y miró a su alrededor, como si estuviera buscando algo o a alguien. Su mirada se encontró con la mía y por un momento, nos quedamos mirándonos fijamente, sin decir nada. Luego, sonrió y se volvió hacia su compañera, que seguía con los ojos cerrados, y le susurró algo al oído. La otra joven abrió los ojos y las dos se miraron entre sí, y luego se rieron, como si compartieran un secreto que nadie más conocía. El sofá seguía en silencio, pero ahora parecía estar esperando a que las dos jóvenes tomaran la iniciativa de hacer algo. Y entonces, sin previo aviso, la habitación se llenó de una luz cegadora y todo desapareció.

Me acerqué a ella con cautela, intentando no hacer ruido, y me detuve a unos pasos de distancia, observándola con curiosidad. La habitación estaba en silencio, excepto por el sonido de su respiración, que era lenta y profunda. Me pregunté qué había pasado para que se hubiera quedado callada durante tanto tiempo, y qué había provocado su repentino grito de sorpresa. Me acerqué un poco más, intentando ver su rostro, pero ella no se movió ni me miró. Su silencio era tan absoluto que me sentí incómodo, y comencé a sentir una sensación de inquietud en el estómago. De repente, se movió, y su voz volvió a sonar, esta vez con una nota de sorpresa y curiosidad en su tono. "¿Qué hora es?", preguntó, como si no recordara que era de noche, y su pregunta me hizo sentir aún más incómodo, ya que sabía que era tarde, muy tarde.

The look on your face told me everything – a mix of guilt and panic that I'd seen before, but never from you. The room fell silent, the only sound being the soft hum of the air conditioner in the background, a stark contrast to the tension that filled the air. I took a step closer, my eyes locked onto yours, searching for any sign of remorse or regret, but all I saw was a desperate attempt to deflect the blame. “What happened, Tom?” I asked, my voice firm but laced with a hint of concern. “Tell me the truth.”

The nurse handed me a mirror, and I caught a glimpse of myself, pale and disheveled, with dark circles under my eyes. I looked like I'd been through a war, and in a way, I had. The pain was still throbbing, but it was nothing compared to the emptiness I felt inside. Tom was supposed to be here, holding my hand, smiling at me, but he was nowhere to be found. I tried to call out for him, but my voice was hoarse from the anesthesia, and all that came out was a weak whisper. The nurse patted my hand and told me not to worry, that Tom would be back soon, but I knew better. He'd been acting strange all day, and I had a feeling he was going to be a lot more absent than I'd anticipated. I thought back to the argument we'd had the night before, the one that had left me feeling like I was walking on eggshells around him. I wondered if that was the last time I'd ever see him, if he'd ever come back to me, or if I'd be raising our daughter on my own. The thought sent a chill down my spine, and I felt a single tear roll down my cheek. I quickly wiped it away, not wanting to show weakness in front of the nurse, but it was too late. She'd already seen it, and her expression was sympathetic. "It's okay, dear," she said softly. "You're going to be just fine." But I wasn't so sure.

Me senté en el borde de la silla, a su lado, y miré hacia su rostro, tratando de descubrir qué había sucedido para que se durmiera de esa manera. De repente, escuché un ruido suave proveniente de la mesa de su escritorio, y me di la vuelta para ver qué era. Era un papel que se había caído de su escritorio y se había deslizado por el suelo. Me sentí un poco nervioso al pensar en qué podría decir, pero mi curiosidad me impulsó a leerla. La nota decía: "No te fiar de nadie, especialmente de los que parecen ser tus amigos". The sound of the camera crew packing up their equipment and the distant hum of the partygoers faded into the background as I turned to Daisy and whispered, "I think it's time for us to go." en_results_raw: The quiet lights in the houses across the street cast a warm glow on the pavement, and the air was filled with the sweet scent of ripe fruit from the nearby orchard. They stood there for a moment, the only sound being the distant hum of a car driving by and the soft crunch of leaves beneath their feet. The woman's eyes sparkled in the dim light, and the man's eyes locked onto hers, his expression a mix of nostalgia and longing. They had been together for a long time, but in this moment, it felt like they were two strangers who had just met, the world around them melting away. The woman's voice was barely above a whisper as she spoke, her words hanging in the air like a promise. "Do you remember that night?" she asked, her eyes never leaving his. The man's face softened, and he nodded slowly, a small smile playing on his lips. They stood there for a moment longer, the silence between them thick with unspoken words and memories. Then, without another word, they turned and walked on, their footsteps echoing through the quiet night, the moonlight casting an ethereal glow on their figures as they disappeared into the darkness.

Me encanta caminar por la Quinta Avenida, ver a la gente de todas las edades y culturas, y sentir el ritmo de la ciudad que nunca duerme. Los cines de la calle Cincuenta son un refugio acogedor en medio de la agitación urbana, un lugar donde puedo perderme en una película y olvidar por un rato la realidad. Pero hoy, Jordan me ha convencido de que vayamos a ver una película en el cine más pequeño de la ciudad, uno de esos lugares que parecen haber salido de una película de Woody Allen. Es un lugar oscuro y acogedor, con butacas cómodas y una pantalla grande que parece haber sido diseñada para proyectar películas clásicas. Me siento un poco nervioso, no sé qué película vamos a ver, pero estoy emocionado de descubrirlo. Jordan se sienta a mi lado y me sonríe, y yo me siento agradecido de tener a alguien que me acompañe en esta aventura. La película comienza y nos sumergimos en un mundo de fantasía y aventuras, y por un rato, olvidamos de la ciudad bulliciosa que nos rodea.

en_results_raw: The other driver, a young man with a look of shock on his face, had swerved to avoid us and in doing so, had clipped our car's side mirror. My friend's wife, who had been white-knuckling the steering wheel, let out a small gasp as our car careened to the side of the road. I, trying to reassure her, reached out and placed a calming hand on her shoulder. She looked at me with a mixture of fear and gratitude in her eyes, and I could see the tension in her body begin to ease. The woman who had rushed out in front of us, a middle-aged woman with a look of concern on her face, approached our car and apologized profusely for her actions, explaining that she had been distracted by a phone call and hadn't seen us coming. My friend, still shaken, got out of the car to inspect the damage, while I stayed with his wife, trying to keep her calm. As we stood there, I couldn't help but think about how easily things could have turned out differently. The woman who had caused the accident could have been more careful, or the other driver could have swerved in the opposite direction. But fate had other plans, and we were left to deal with the aftermath of a close call. My friend's wife, still shaken, asked me if I was okay, and I nodded, trying to reassure her that I was fine. She smiled weakly and thanked me for being there for her, and I could see the gratitude in her eyes. As we stood there, I couldn't help but think about how this close call had brought us closer together, and how it had reminded me of the importance of being present in the moment. The woman who had caused the accident was still standing there, looking contrite, and I could see the regret in her eyes. My friend, still inspecting the damage, looked up and nodded at her, and I could sense a sense of understanding between them. It was as if they both knew that accidents happen, and that sometimes it's not about who's to blame, but about how we respond to them. As we stood there, I couldn't help but feel a sense of gratitude for the woman who had caused the accident, for she had brought us closer together, and had reminded us of the importance of being present in the moment. The sun was beginning to set, casting a warm glow over the scene, and I could feel a sense of peace wash over me. It was as if the close call had been a wake-up call, a reminder to appreciate the beauty in the world around us, and to cherish the time we have with each other. As we stood there, I knew that this close call would stay with me forever, a reminder of the fragility of life, and the importance of living in the present moment.

The silence was oppressive, a heavy blanket that wrapped around him, making it hard to breathe. He thought of his wife, who had passed away a year ago, and the countless memories they had made in this very room, the laughter, the arguments, the quiet moments of tenderness. He felt a lump form in his throat as he gazed around at the empty spaces, the echoes of their lives together still lingering in the air. The door creaked softly in the breeze, a mournful sound that seemed to whisper his name, and he felt a shiver run down his spine. He took a deep breath, trying to shake off the feeling of sadness that had settled over him, but it clung to him like a damp mist, refusing to let go. As he stood there, frozen in time, the world outside seemed to fade away, leaving only the memories, the what-ifs, and the ache of loss.

en_first_half: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent
en_second_half: sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
en_results: The housekeeper, Mrs. Jenkins, had been acting strangely all morning, and I couldn't shake the feeling that she knew more than she was letting on. I decided to approach her in the kitchen, where she was busily
en_results_raw: The housekeeper, Mrs. Jenkins, had been acting strangely all morning, and I couldn't shake the feeling that she knew more than she was letting on. I decided to approach her in the kitchen, where she was busily preparing lunch, and clear the air once and for all. "Mrs. Jenkins," I said, trying to sound casual, "I wanted to speak with you about something before I leave." She looked up from the stove, her expression a mask of innocence, and I wondered if I was reading too much into things. "Of course, sir," she replied, her voice neutral. I took a deep breath and plunged ahead, trying to get the words out before I lost my nerve. "I know it's none of my business, but I couldn't help but notice that you've been acting... differently lately. Is everything all right?" Mrs. Jenkins' expression didn't change, but I could sense a flicker of something behind her eyes, a hint of unease that she quickly suppressed. I pressed on, my heart pounding in my chest. "I just want to make sure that everything is in order before I go," I said, trying to sound reassuring. "I don't want to leave you with any... any worries." Mrs. Jenkins nodded, her face a picture of calm, but I could tell she was hiding something. I decided to take a chance and ask her directly. "Mrs. Jenkins, is there something you're not telling me?" The words hung in the air, and for a moment, I thought I saw a glimmer of fear in her eyes. But then, just as quickly, it was gone, replaced by her usual mask of indifference. I was left standing there, feeling foolish and unsure of what to do next.

es_first_half: Había algo que tenía que hacer antes de irme, algo desagradable y embarazoso que probablemente hubiera sido mejor no hacer. Pero quería dejarlo todo en orden y no confiar en que el mar indiferente y diligente
es_second_half: se llevara mi basura. Vi a Jordan Baker y hablé de lo que había pasado entre nosotros, y de lo que después me había pasado a mí, y ella me escuchó, muy quieta, en un gran sillón.
es_results: de la casa de mis sueños me lo hiciera por mí. Así que me dirigí a la habitación que había estado evitando durante días, la que contenía recuerdos de mi pasado y objetos que me recordaban
es_results_raw: de la casa de mis sueños me lo hiciera por mí. Así que me dirigí a la habitación que había estado evitando durante días, la que contenía recuerdos de mi pasado y objetos que me recordaban a ella. Me senté en la cama, rodeado de fotos y recuerdos que parecían hablar de una vida que ya no era mía. Me puse de pie y comencé a recoger los papeles y objetos que había acumulado durante años, tratando de deshacerme de todo lo que me recordaba a ella. Pero cada objeto que tocaba me hacía sentir una mezcla de tristeza y nostalgia, como si estuviera despidiéndome de una parte de mí mismo. Finalmente, después de lo que pareció una eternidad, terminé de recoger todo y me senté en la cama, exhausto y con la sensación de que había cerrado un capítulo de mi vida. Pero justo cuando pensaba que había terminado, escuché un ruido detrás de mí y me di la vuelta para ver a alguien que me miraba con una sonrisa triste en el rostro.
